I, Suchiguma (you may call me sushi or sushigummy if that's easier), am the main author of this website, which contains several guides and resources for Azur Lane endgame.
I specialize in crafting fleet/gear strategy for endgame PvE battles. These are some examples of my achievements:
EX: Usually top 3 EX score across EN servers. And I got wrongfully suspended one time. Then Yostar repealed the ban and gave me jack shit for missing a whole day of research, rewards, and opsi.
Extreme Challenge: Auto speedruns with the world's fastest or near-fastest clear times in multiple months.
Hard Arbiter: Auto speedruns like killing each arbiter in 21 seconds using faster but lower-damage gear.

A long, long time ago (but after EN servers' beta period), I was a clueless little new player. I found some deteriorating (and, in hindsight, often questionable) guides on the street and perused them diligently along with the EN wiki, helping me clear Chapter 12 with ease. However, as a casual player, I fell victim to mistakes such as retiring ships after level 70 MLB for the noble but misguided ideal of clearing dock space; some of the ships lost in the great purges offered key level 120 tech stats (sorry, Intrepid and Eskimo).

Sometime in late 2020, I began taking the game more seriously. I farmed 12-2 and 12-4 with a 1:3 fleet and even wrote a simulation to calculate when to retreat from 12-4 for maximum ship experience gains (this was before clearing rewards were added for completing the boss battle). However, mobilizing my account to handle the endgame content of the time proved slow, and I failed to one-shot Hiryuu META and Ark Royal META when Operation Siren released.

Fast forward a few years, and it seems I've made rather respectable progress, despite my dubious beginnings. Today, Iâ€™m hailed as one of the most eminent scholars of my field. My journey proves that I...I forgot the point of writing this story.
I hang out in the
Azur Lane Official Discord
If you have a general gameplay question that can be formulated outside the context of this website, then ask in the #gameplay-help channel there. You may or may not ping me.
If your gameplay question must mention some content in this website, then either ask in the #gameplay-help channel there but do NOT ping me, or direct message me @suchiguma.

Note that I will not accept low-effort or easy questions in DMs. My DMs are reserved for feedback or complex/important questions about my guides or content that you do not trust #gameplay-help with. Please also direct fleet-building help or dock/account help to #gameplay-help.
If you have a strong account and don't want to learn, copy your homework from this page.
If you want to learn or don't have a strong account, then read both this page and
Chapter 14 Detailed
We are writing this guide almost a year later than the
Chapter 15 guide

because many new players seem to get stuck at various points in Chapter 14, 15, and 11-3. Although Chapter 15 fleets work for 14 too, there are some optimizations that enable players to get away with weaker fleets in 14. So this guide is for first-time clearing Chapter 14 on auto in lethal threat level, with manual enemy node selection.

Three star can use any of the non-budget fleets because Chapter 14 isn't too difficult. Auto search on safe threat for farming New Orleans can also use the exact same fleets because safe threat makes it easy even through two out of ammo mob battles.

Tip: Stagger (desync) your main fleet's damage! Make them attack at different times, preferably with a gap of 1.5s or more between their launches. Note that BB guns will begin to hit right away, while carriers need 3 to 4 seconds to land their ordnance, which could cause  overlap.
Apparently this does need to be said, but at this point, level 120 ships and +10 gear are the absolute minimum. Attempting to bring a shiny new level 110 UR with one limit break is not a good idea.
Tip: Fleet screenshots using
Azur Lane Fleet Tool
show the vanguard from bottom (main-tank) to top (off-tank). It's like the in-game Formation screen but rotated counter-clockwise. The ships are also marked with 1, 2, and 3 from bottom to top.

Avoid: summoning submarines at the beginning of a battle.

Summoning submarines early in battle means that they surface and die. Summon them 15 to 25 seconds into the battle so that you win before they run out of oxygen. You know roughly how long your battles take.

Chapter 14 Brief
If you have reached Chapter 14, we assume you know basic fleet building, fleet positioning, and basic game terminology like BB, CV, ASW, and concealment. Read
wiki notes
for mechanics introduced by Chapter 14. You can skip it and just follow or copy this guide, but if things go wrong then it would be helpful to know why they went wrong.
Please know what
concealment and detection
mean, at least for the main fleet.
Now let's discuss the four main threats in Chapter 14 first. These are BBs, airplanes, suicide boats, and submarines.
Chapter 14 isn't the first place where enemy BBs can deal significant damage to your main fleet. What
is

new is that there can be three or even four enemy BBs on screen at once. Also, your own BB is now concealed, which means enemies can blind fire your squishy CV(L) instead of focusing on your tanky BB.

content.alt: An enemy mass-produced BB blind-fires PainlevÃ©.

content.text: Blind-fire occurs when your whole main fleet is concealed. In this image, the production-type BB fired two volleys of two HE shells at PainlevÃ©. If they hit, HE shells do some damage and have a chance to set a fire for a lot more damage. Burning causes your ship's detection gauge to increase. If revealed, the ship will be focus-fired by all enemy BBs for massive damage.

Your top main fleet ship seems to be more likely to receive shelling than your bottom main fleet ship. It may be because more enemy BBs spawn in the top lane, BBs in the top lane stay alive for longer, or both. Put your more-fragile carrier in the bottom.
Do not use Bowguns or Hunting Bows, because EVA stat is better.
Minimize enemy BBs' opportunities to do damage by staggering your main fleet attacks and clearing enemy waves quickly.

There are much fewer airplanes than in Chapter 13. Thus, the airplanes can't do much damage to your main fleet...or can they? As mentioned in the wiki section about detection, whenever an airplane reaches your main fleet, all of your main fleets' detection gauges increase. And if a ship gets revealed through some combination of fires and airplanes, then she will be targeted by all BBs.

The key to killing sparse squadrons of airplanes consistently is range, because airplanes usually need to be hit twice to die. In the image, the enemy Yamashiro launches planes directly into the player's high AA gun range, and the airplanes will get hit a second time with high probability. High range also applies to airplanes that come from the right of the screen; it decreases the probability of airplane leaks due to your vanguard's random movement.

There are two types of suicide boats in Chapter 14, the usual fast Bombing Ship with about 900 HP and the Kagerou Production unique to Chapter 14. Each Kagerou Production has over 9,000 HP (okay, over 10,000) and a frontal shield that can block 32 shells from your vanguard guns or BB auxiliary guns.

If any suicide boat survives, it deals high damage and increases your main fleet's detection gauge. If you've been reading this guide in order, then you know why that is significant. Thanks to the shield, most fleets won't be able to kill Kagerou Productions purely with vanguard guns and BB aux guns while having ammo, let alone when out of ammo. So you will need help from other damage sources like bombs, BB shells, torpedoes, and skill barrages.
Tip: Stagger your main fleet attacks and vanguard torpedoes both to clear enemy waves quickly and to randomly hit Kagerou Productions.

There are too many variables at play here to test which CL or DD gun is the best for BBs. And nowadays, Chapter 14 is not difficult or interesting enough to encourage someone to spend hours on testing. Hence, we prepared the following list based on logic and various players' observations.
Neptune gun
completely flunks the prerequisite of high shell count.
Plymouth gun
only fires 4 shells and doesn't have great damage, so it's probably not good despite being able to pierce and being rainbow.
Triple 155mm
and its
Eagle Union counterpart
fire 6 shells and do high damage against light armor, but their fixed spread patterns may not be ideal.
Triple 155mm Kai
and
Twin 137mm

are the usual recommendations because they fire 6 shells and have reasonable chances to hit. Triple 155mm Kai does more damage per shell, while Twin 137mm has zero spread and can pierce. Pierce is nice because sometimes a Bombing Ship hides behind a Kagerou Production.

Enemy submarines only appear in 14-3 and 14-4, and they appear only in Reconnaissance Fleets (a.k.a. DD nodes). Due to their concealment, submarines often can dodge some depth charges. You should bring more ASW in your mob fleet than a single
Hedgehog
and the default depth charges. Options include the purple Improved Depth Charge, the ASW airplanes like
Gannet
, and Eldridge Retrofit. Leaked submarines deal high damage and, for the fourth time in this guide, increases your main fleet's detection gauge.
There are lots of enemy torpedoes, so the
Anti-Torpedo Bulge
can help cruisers.

Capturing the lighthouse as early as possible is a good idea for most fleets. However, players have reported mixed results with flares. Theoretically, flares can help wipe out the enemy Kagerou Productions and elite chibis if your main fleet attack is timed with the flare. However, flares come with several downsides. Lighthouses have the same downsides, but they are less impactful.

Your main fleet ships tend to target enemies revealed by flares, which are usually Kagerou Productions or an elite chibi DD/CL/CA. This focus can leave the dangerous production BBs in the back alive for longer.
Flaring an enemy does not permanently reveal it. Instead, the enemy's concealment is
temporarily

set to 0. After the flare expires or the enemy exits the flare's range, the enemy's concealment instantly returns to its previous value. That makes the enemy stay concealed for longer and is a loss for you if you don't manage to deal significant damage during the flare.
14-1 is the tutorial of the chapter. Put your knowledge of Threats and General Tips to good use, or copy the example fleets.

14-2 has a much more dangerous boss battle than 14-1 does, despite both bosses being BBVs with similar stats. The reason is that 14-1's boss phase starts with one production BB, and only an AA ship and a Bombing Ship respawn regularly. 14-2's boss phase has two production BBs that respawn regularly along with an AA ship, two Bombing Ships, and a Kagerou Production. They slap both your top and bottom main fleet ships and act as more targets and HP you need to deal with.
Enemy submarines appear in Reconnaissance Fleets (DD nodes) in 14-3 and 14-4. Your mob fleet must bring ASW.
Technically, you could fight BB nodes only, but thatâ€™s harder.

The bosses in 14-3 are two light armor DDs, and the respawning reinforcements include only one production BB, one AA ship, one CA, and two Bombing Ships. You might find this easier to deal with than the 14-2 boss.

Do not be tempted to use HVAR Hellcat or Skyraider for anti-light. You will grief your ability to deal with the pre-boss waves (which contain a lot of heavy armor) as well as the production BBs in the boss wave. Similarly, avoid BF-109G or La-9 against any Chapter 14 enemy; the most you might want to risk is a single rocket fighter in a smaller airplane slot. Rockets also deal with concealed enemies poorly.

14-4 has seven mob battles, but there is an ammo node available. The boss battle has four waves of enemies before the boss spawns, three of which contain BBs. In the boss wave, regular reinforcements include two production BBs, two AA ships, and three Bombing Ships. The whole boss battle is very long and punishing.
Recommendation: If you can't three star on lethal, then don't. Safe threat level gives your fleet like +20% damage dealt and -36% damage taken.

Use cats, they do not have to be perfect. Random level 30 cats boost your fleet by 10-20%, and perfect cats boost even more. Important talents: Mountain on mob = Flame when out of ammo > Flame when with ammo = Mountain on boss > other stuff.
Quit and retry a battle if you get unlucky. Maybe your main fleet got burnt or revealed too early, or your vanguard ate too many torpedoes.
Check the tier list on the
home page
for what ships are good, and sort by Chapter 14 Mob/Boss.

This guide is for first-time clearing Chapter 15 on auto in lethal threat level, with manual enemy node selection. Auto search on safe threat for farming Houston II is not covered (maybe just take 15-4 Option A and add a healer to the boss fleet).
If you have reached Chapter 15, we assume you know basic fleet building, fleet positioning, and basic game terminology like BB, AA, and ASW.
Read
wiki notes
for mechanics. Read the "Allied Support Carriers" point very carefully.

Same as in Chapter 14, X-1 and X-2 form the tutorial and X-3 and X-4 are much harder. The enemy order here is six mobs, one boss. The 15-1 boss has medium armor and the 15-2 boss has heavy armor. Both your mob and boss fleets need to contain decent ships and gear. There is nothing notable about 15-1, as itâ€™s a tutorial to Chapter 15.
The boss in 15-2 is a double BBV boss, Ise and Hyuuga. Their shelling can delete a full HP main fleet ship in the span of three seconds. Putting a
washing machine

and EVA augment (Scepter or Officer's Sword) on your main fleet ships, especially the flagship, is strongly recommended for 15-2 only. Be prepared to quit the battle and retry. Summon submarines just before the bosses spawn, so they can help delete the bosses quicker. If you choose to manual, use airstrikes to cancel the bossesâ€™ salvos.
Enemy submarines appear in Reconnaissance Fleets (DD nodes) in 15-3 and 15-4. Your mob fleet must bring ASW.
Technically, you could fight BB nodes and CV nodes only, but thatâ€™s certainly harder.

The enemy order in 15-3 is three mobs, medium armor first boss, two mobs, medium armor second boss. The same boss fleet you used for 15-1 and 15-2 should be able to handle the second boss. But now, your mob fleet has to deal with submarines and a tough first boss. Strongly consider shifting some better gear and/or ships to the mob fleet if your boss fleet is not struggling.
The enemy order in 15-4 is three mobs, medium armor first boss, two mobs, light armor second boss, one mob, light/medium armor third boss.

You can use either your mob fleet or your boss fleet to fight each of the three bosses. So there are 2^3 = 8 ways to assign your fleets to the bosses. This bar chart approximates how strong your mob and boss fleets need to be, for six of eight ways. The leftmost four orders are recommended, while the rightmost two are not. The chart and recommendations assume that Clearing Mode is OFF, so the Data Analyzed debuff will apply, and MMM and BBB are excluded for obvious reasons.

A very strong boss fleet fights the first and third bosses (BMB). Try to not spend more than 25% of any shipâ€™s HP in the first boss battle. Using a healer with good damage like Volga is reasonable, but damage is still important.

The mob fleet can be about as strong as the 15-3 mob fleet. You have access to an ammo node, and the second boss is a pushover and acts as free healing if you are using two healers. The only harder parts compared to 15-3 are that enemies are one level higher and that there are two Special Aviation Fleets.
A very strong mob fleet fights all mobs, first boss, and third boss (MBM).
Since the "boss fleet" is only dealing with an easy second boss, you can add crossfleet ships to help the mob fleet. The boss fleet can look like UR BB, Independence, Perseus, tank, flex, flex.
Option B is also the most consistent strategy to defeat all mobs to get the third star on lethal threat level. To get the third star, we recommend this order.
Do NOT use the ammo node early.
Fight two Special Aviation Fleets.
Fight one more enemy. We want to prioritize Large Main Fleets while the mob fleet still has ammo. If there are none, choose a Large Air Formation or whatever is hardest.
Fight Boss 1 and then one more enemy following the same order as in Step 2. Now, the mob fleet is out of ammo. Choose a hard enemy if your fleet is healthy, otherwise choose an easy enemy.
Use the "boss fleet" for Boss 2.
Reserve two Medium or Large Reconnaissance fleets and Boss 3 until the end. Use your mob fleet to fight everything else.
Pick up the full 3 ammo node, clear the last two Reconnaissance fleets to hopefully heal up, and clear Boss 3.
Recommendation: If you can't three star on lethal, then don't. Safe threat level gives your fleet like +20% damage dealt and -36% damage taken.
Mob fleet: UR BB, 2 healer CV/CVLs, tank, flex, flex.
Boss fleet: UR BB, 2 damage CV/CVLs, tank, flex, flex.
The flex slots should not be squishy and should contribute survivability, AA, and/or damage. Add ASW in the 15-3/15-4 mob fleet. Good ships can contribute two or three or even four of these.
You
can

bring a single healer like Unicorn for the mob fleet, but it adds inconsistency and makes recovering from suicide boat leaks or submarine leaks extremely difficult. Solo healer is great when your fleet is very strong, but if you have a great fleet and account then you're winning with or without a second healer anyways.

For the boss fleet damage carriers, you may use a semi-preload like Independence or Impero to deal with the pre-boss waves quicker. These two also have strong damage for the boss anyways. If you use two normal-reload carriers, then try to desync them.

Carrier level, AVI, and RLD matter. Affinity affects AVI and RLD. You should get all support carriers to at least level 120 and Love affinity because Chapter 15 is not the place to be cutting corners at. The equipped fighter and the fighter enhancement level matter. The DB or TB can be any enhancement level and any plane, just have gold or rainbow for +45 or +65 avi stat.
Assuming all have equal level, affinity, and gear etc., the best support fleet carriers are, in
slightly

decreasing order of strength: Fritz Rumey much stronger, Hwah Jah (Retrofit), Nakhimov (REQUIRES DEV 30), Indomitable, Implacable, Illustrious, Illustrious Âµ, Chen Hai (Retrofit), Little Illustrious, Langley (Retrofit), Yorktown II, Independence, Albion, Centaur.
Slightly
means slightly; it's ok to use a more accessible ship lower on the list.
The best support fighter is tested to be the new
by a small margin. It also happens to be quite cheap to craft in Gear Lab for a gold gear. The next bests are
Flapjack
and
Hellcat
, followed by
Skyrocket
Me-155A
, and
fw190a5
. If you are on a budget, prioritize Flapjacks for the surface fleets.
They are all similar, pick any three SR subs. Many bonus points for high oxygen, some bonus points for fleet synergy.
Use Improved Snorkel on everyone.
Use any mix of
Bidder
G7e
, or
Type 95 Kai
, or use six of the same, it doesnâ€™t matter.
Submarines should be used on all boss battles (but optional for 15-4â€™s second boss), so reserve ammo for those. Spend the other ammo on out-of-ammo battles or the Special Aviation Fleet.
Avoid: summoning submarines at the beginning of a battle.

Summoning submarines early in battle means that they surface and die. Summon them 20 to 40 seconds into the battle so that you win before they run out of oxygen. You know roughly how long your battles take.
If you havenâ€™t been playing Operation Siren, you probably wonâ€™t win in Chapter 15. Lots of the best gear is in Gear Lab, and +13 gear is a huge boost in strength.
Bring Hedgehog and at least one other ASW weapon on the mob fleet for 15-3 and 15-4. Options include a
Fairey Gannet
or
TBM Avenger VT-51
on a CVL, a purple depth charge, or Eldridge (Retrofit).
Mob fleet BB wants
457mm
Twin 410 kai
for Musashi). Boss fleet BB can use another 457mm or a 20s triple gun like
champ gun
For BB aux guns,
Quad 152
137mm

Mob and boss fleet fighters:

Tigercat
corsair pirate squad

> poverty.
AA guns:
UR Twin 76mm
STAAG
for main fleet,
Sextuple
for the strongest AA gun slot, and some mix of UR Twin 76mm,

, Sextuple, or
Twin 113mm
for the rest. Obviously, the more rainbow AA, the better. Use any Twin 57mm you already have, but for any new crafts or +13's, choose Twin 76mm because it's useful literally everywhere.
Auxes: standard auxes, but vanguard ships (especially if the middle slot is not a DD) can use anti-torpedo bulges if they are not occupied with ASW.

Use cats, they do not have to be perfect. Random level 30 cats boost your fleet by 10-20%, and perfect cats boost even more. Important talents: Mountain on mob = Flame when out of ammo > Flame when with ammo = Mountain on boss > other stuff.
Use double line or circular formation, never single line, depending on how good your fleetâ€™s AA is.
Kill the enemy Special Aviation Fleet at the beginning of each sortie by moving the blocker Reconnaissance fleet out of the way.
Avoid Large/Medium Main Fleets. If you're 3 starring, use Shimanto and/or Musashi, and never fight them when out of ammo.
If your whole main fleet with Musashi is constantly going to low HP due to airplanes, give Musashi an
AA Radar
to let her resist air damage.
If your whole main fleet without Musashi is constantly going to low HP due to airplanes, get better AA, not AA Radars.

the best ships for Chapter 15 include CBs, CLs, and even several DDs. Raffaello and Zuihou heal DDs very well, so this mob vanguard will be invincible. Yes, there are better, newer ships that let you win even harder. We won't update this fleet every month.

Warning: The efficiency buffs of Shoukaku, Centaur, Taihou, Hood, and Long Island are bugged since release to be 1/10 as effective, causing up to 7% damage loss. We rate them as if they were not bugged.
Added Shoukaku and Grozny augments on July 12, 2025.

The cores and experience stones needed to craft and upgrade unique augments are time-gated. Currently, it is impossible to have crafted and maxed all unique augments released in the game. Meta-chasing and new players need to choose carefully which ships to craft augments for. Thus, this augment module tier list was made to rate the effectiveness and worth of each augment to help you make those decisions.
Read the
Augmentation
wiki page for how to get, upgrade, and use augments.

content.html:
EXPAND TO SEE THE RUBRIC.

Gain

Gain for unique augments rates the overall benefit the augment brings to the ship over a generic purple augment (or no augment, for ships who can't use purple augments). This includes damage, survivability, buffing, and everything. The relative strength of the ship does not matter; a +50% damage boost for a weak ship should be rated the same as a +50% damage boost for a strong ship.

Worth

Worth is subjective. If you must use a waifu no matter what, then of course her augment would be very much worth. So the "worth" ratings in the table roughly follows this rubric:
  • Has sizeable gain for a ship who sees various endgame use.
  • Has sizeable gain for a ship who is good in at least some endgame content and has few other substitutes.
  • Makes the ship useful for midgame to lategame.
  • Makes the ship decent but not meta.
  • Worse than or equal to purple augments, or the augmented ship would still be bad.

New SKK

Rates "worth" for new players, covering your first two or three unique augments or until you reach "midgame" (farming Chapter 12 or beating Abyssal zones). Obviously, do not craft the unique augment of a ship you don't own.... And this tier list should not force you to obtain a ship. Just because an augment is S-tier doesn't mean you should try your hardest to get that ship.
  • The most important in helping a new player reach midgame.
  • Very helpful for a new player to reach midgame.
  • Good to have as a new player but maybe a bit out of order.
  • Diverts resources away from far more important augments or outlives its usefulness quickly.
  • Simply a waste of augment resources for a new player.

Collabs

Collab augments are cheaper to max level, and this cheapness is included in both "worth" ratings for all players and for new players. If an old collab augment is said to be worth for new players, obviously new new players can't get them (or the ships) anymore. So it is just there for new players who got the ship and augment, then quit the game and recently returned.

content.text: Note: New players should save up for impactful unique augments instead of crafting or upgrading blue/purple augments.
These are special cases. Their worth cannot be judged because they are completely free or have non-combat effects.

Each month's page will have strategies and several example fleets. Although we try to be detailed in strategies and provide multiple example fleets, we do not know what ships or gear you have. Treat the example fleets as examples, and consider your own better upgrades or close substitutes.
Warning: Do not treat examples as requirements. New Jersey's presence in an example fleet is not an endorsement for using UR bulins on her.

We assume Hard (Augur) difficulty, but the same strategies usually work for lower difficulties with worse fleets and gear. We also assume auto battle only, because most of the difficult CM gimmicks are nullified by proper manualing.
Always check boss stats and skills on
Extreme Challenge
wiki (or in game, but sometimes the game says a wrong number).
Tip: Fleet screenshots using
Azur Lane Fleet Tool
show the vanguard from bottom (main-tank) to top (off-tank). It's like the in-game Formation screen but rotated counter-clockwise. The ships are also marked with 1, 2, and 3 from bottom to top.

Most CM's are exercises in reading and timing. Oaths or exact gear levels (+10 to +13) are not required unless for timing. However, many example fleets are timing-sensitive, and you often won't have the exact ships, oaths, gear, cat RLD, and RLD tech to copy them correctly. Then, you will need to calculate your own fleet timing. To the best of our knowledge,
this online calculator
henceforth referred to as "the calculator"
, is the only one that is precise enough for these CM timing calculations. We highly recommend not being scared by it and learning how to use it on desktop.

If an example fleet requires "50 CV RLD with oath", that means you need oathed CVs and have CV reload from tech + cats = 50. Alternatively, it would also probably work without oaths and with CV tech + cats = 57 or 58.

Due to how the game code loop works, some boss skills, boss movement patterns, or ship skills can be delayed by 0.0s to 0.1s every time. This is more noticeable in long battles like the game mode this guide is for. Some strategies attempt to account for this delay, but sometimes it can't be fixed.

This month is a straight DPS and reading check. Light status = shielded = healing 1% HP per second. Dark status = easy mode. Bring vanguard ships that spam a lot of shells to break the shield as fast as possible, because you do not want to let Katsuragi heal 15% HP for every 30% lost. Other than the vanguard shell spam, there are no other gimmicks, so bring typical good anti-medium DPS. We only provide examples of fleets with good synergy and sync to attain high DPS. If you do not know how to set up high DPS fleets in the absence of boss gimmicks by yourself, we recommend asking or lurking in
ALO Discord
#gameplay-help.
Note: Katsuragi's movement cycle is approximately 28.45s long, so you should bring your own slow/freeze.

Although Katsuragi's skill descriptions imply that the five rotating shields can each block 70 shells, in reality they share the same hit count. So if 70 shells each hit any of the shields, all five shields disappear, and Katsuragi enters Dark status. Furthermore, like typical rotating shields, her shields will not block arcing shells from BB guns, CB guns, torpedos, and bombs. Katsuragi also often moves back to the far right of the screen (as 13-4 Taihou does when carpet bombing).
Taking this information into consideration, some example favored and unfavored things are listed here:
Things that are good against Katsuragi.
Twin 138.6mm and both Twin 130mm's have high range and shells per second.
Twin 100mm Kai has high shells per second and spams barrages, but is more inconsistent due to low range.
Plymouth has 3 main gun mounts (MGMs) and a guaranteed aimed barrage every 10s.
San Diego and Scylla spam shells and have good AA to keep carriers concealed, though Sandy's augment barrage ignores shields.
Helena has 2 CL MGMs and 1 DD mount.
Barrage or MGM spammers like Mogador, Harbin, Tai Yuan > other DDGs, or Tashkent(s).
Things that may be good in general but are less so against Katsuragi.
Triple 155mm Kai or any other slow gun.
CA guns have low shells per second.
CBs (and basically all CAs) have poor shield-breaking capabilities, and their tankiness is not needed.
Hindenburg's guns ignore shields.
Z52's barrages pass through shields, and she only has 1 MGM.

Tempesta submarine frigates can also help break one shield cycle. Summon them a few seconds before you will pass the 30% HP difference since Katsuragi last had shields. Just put cheap gear, no need to spend core data on all the 12-pounders and Round Shots.

This fleet won in 9:58 with half tech, mid cats, and no submarine fleet. Please bring submarines and a bit more +13 or tech. Fritz is not using double BF109G because that would make her too fast. To keep Fritz before AvP, do not exceed 50 CV RLD, but get as high as you can so that Fritz stays synced for longer. Enterprise will desync eventually but not much we can do about it. San Diego may sink after 8 or 9 minutes - level 125 is very important to extend her lifetime.
None. Even the
High-End BB
fleet will take over 6 minutes with half tech and mid cats. Try your best to copy it and make substitutes.

This fleet won in 4:52 with half tech, mid cats, and no subs. For this specific gear and oaths, Nakhimov syncs with Soyuz at 56 CV RLD and 17 BB RLD, or you can subtract an equal amount of RLD from both CVs and BBs (but you lose Helena sync if you subtract too much). Don't forget to decrease your CV tech to use cats with CV RLD. Flandre gun was chosen to keep Helena sync. You may also use
Champagne gun
with 45 CV RLD and 17 BB RLD.
Calculator Link

Plymouth can main tank for 7+ minutes with just one toolkit. Scylla has been unavailable for a while now, so pick a substitute from above if you don't have her. Since Scylla's torpedos are too hard to sync for 10 minutes, we opt for the fastest torps to spam more barrage.

This fleet won in 6:20 with half tech, mid CV-buffing cats, and no subs. There's not much else to explain at this point. As usual for CM, block Bismarck behind Soyuz and/or Alsace so that they stay synced.

This month is a difficult vanguard DPS check. The Jug has 120k HP, 100 EVA, 0 LUCK, and 300 AA. So your vanguard needs to do 2400 damage per second, with a 1.5s starting grace period to do the first 2400 damage whenever the Jug spawns.

This is quite difficult because you can't rely on torpedos, barrages, and long-reload CA guns to do damage consistently (the game calls it "Recurring" damage so we will too). Another pain point is when Newcastle goes in front of the Jug to eat up your vanguard's non-piercing shells, or when Newcastle is above or below the Jug and gets targeted.
Plymouth gun
and
Mogador gun
are highly recommended, but other older AP DD/CL guns are weaker by a lot and not worth using over good HE guns.

Some main fleet ships with 10s attacks or long-range aux guns can also help add recurring damage. Examples include Ulrich, Fritz, Saratoga, or Rupprecht. Submarines or Tempesta IXs can also help for 40s to 60s.
Warning: If your vanguard can't do enough DPS, then don't use low-damage (de)buffers like Aurora, Sirius, or Helena.

But vanguard DPS isn't the whole story. Killing the Jug only gives a 6s window for your main fleet to do full damage to Newcastle, so your main fleet also needs to be synced. Unfortunately for CVs, which require rockets to be good against light armor, having three tightly synced CVs means that some rockets will kill the Jug, some more rockets will hit the water where the Jug was, and only a few rockets will target Newcastle after the Jug dies. Hence, despite the enemy's low AA of 300, CVs are difficult to use. CVs are still better than BBs here if used well with high investment, but that will not be the main focus of this guide.
This section is for manual only, and only months with a notable manual strategy may have a manual section.
Hold your vanguard's torpedoes and drop them on the Jug when it respawns.
This fleet won in 8:39 with mid cats, half tech, and no submarine fleet.

This is a difficult month, so the the fleet should be stronger than the usual "mid". This fleet has semi-high vanguard DPS. But because Plymouth's gun is the only piercing weapon, Ulrich may or may not be needed to help do recurring damage to the Jug. Block Soyuz behind Vanguard, but note that giving Soyuz a Mk7 and Vanguard a Mk6 would not be ideal for sync, so give them the same gun. Also, Ulrich needs to avoid the Mk6/Mk7 reload speed so that she doesn't permanently block Soyuz.
This fleet won in 6:18 with mid cats, half tech, and no submarine fleet.

Bismarck Zwei is highly recommended for more than one reason, but it is still brute force-able with other rainbow BBs. This fleet and similar fleets should work with any BB RLD or oaths. We mention this every month - block the faster BBs behind the slower BB with unequal
AFCT
HSFCR
usage. But this month, Biszwei should go first to pull the Jug and Newcastle together, so we give Soyuz an autoloader to make her reload faster than Biszwei.

Because these rainbow BBs don't contribute recurring damage besides Bisz's Geryon every other salvo, the vanguard absolutely needs to have high DPS. Bisz is flag to get Plymouth's buff because Bisz does the most damage by far. Z52's debuff only applies when the above-flag BB fires, so Bisz's first volley of each salvo won't get it. But it's a minor loss, and Plymouth and Z52 are both still worth using.
Wait, 2 BB 1 CV counts as a CV fleet? Too bad, take it or leave it. There aren't enough high-damage carriers who can stagger to make a real strategy for CVs.

The firing order is Bisz, then Soyuz, then Nakhimov. Bisz and Nakhimov should have the same reload time, only Bisz has -15% first load time. The BBs kill the Jug, then Nakhimov's rockets target Newcastle. Soyuz should fire after Bisz so that she can hit both targets, and so that her slow persists until Nakhimov's payload hits. If Soyuz's barrage activates too early, then Nakhimov may not get her +40% crit damage. That's why Soyuz in this example has an autoloader that's higher than +0 but not too high.

Bisz is once again ideal. Another UR BB can work, but if she and Soyuz fail to kill the Jug, then Nakhimov's airstrike is wasted. Bisz allows Nakhimov to splash both the Jug and Newcastle with high probability even if the Jug is still alive.
calculator link
This video copies a similar strategy from 2024. Bisz pulls the Jug and Newcastle together, and Yorkii rockets them. Kearsarge does her own thing because she's really slow.

Not much strategy, just have high tech/gear/cats. Enterprise can be faster or slower than Yorkii, doesn't really matter. But we would guess that Enterprise being faster is better in this case, so that her rockets don't hit the water every time. There is a lot of lost potential because you kill the Jug at random times, and whether another main fleet ship attacks Newcastle in the next 6s is up to chance. Brute force is brute force.

Fritz is an upgrade over Enterprise. Fritz contributes recurring damage and does a lot more damage than a 70% Enterprise. Just make sure to give Fritz and Yorkii slightly different reload times with a difference of at least 0.25s, say.
Someone won in 6:27 with Kear Yorkii Fritz, full +10 gear. But try it yourself.

Heavy armor HP piÃ±atas. Have fun, you get a break until next month's hell. You don't even need to read these bosses' skills.
As is usually the case with multi-boss battles, Bismarck Zwei is the best. But this month's CM is still easy without her.

June
, so look there if you hope for slightly different options to copy.
This section is for manual only, and only months with a notable manual strategy may have a manual section.

Use your vanguard to ram one boss to slow her down. Keep ramming until the two bosses are stacked together. Your main fleet's DPS will be greatly increased due to splash (yes, all kinds of torpedoes do have small splash). Do not bring single-target slows like Eldridge or Aegir because they can separate the bosses.

With half tech, mid cats, and no submarines, this fleet went to 10 minutes, and Duke had 10% HP left. Ark Royal's 60% slow is not reliable because the bosses move in a circle constantly. Perhaps replacing Ibuki with Helena and adding some more +13 airplanes would win.

This fleet won in 5:45 with mid cats and no submarines. It's a standard single-target anti-heavy boss fleet with such high DPS that it doesn't matter if the fleet can only damage one boss with each airstrike, or if the fleet damages alternating bosses every airstrike. Because the reload times are so close together, to ensure the correct airstrike order of Amagi CV, Implacable, then Shinano, the flagship is Amagi despite her distance skill preferring off flag.

This fleet won in 4:25 with mid cats and no submarines. Bismarck Zwei pulls the bosses together, and CV torpedoes can often splash both bosses. The timing is very strict. For an unoathed main fleet, this works with 54 CV RLD and 0 BB RLD. For oathed, it's 58 CV and 0 BB. If you're missing 2 or 3 CV RLD, swap Bishamaru to the staff cat position, although this will separate Shinano and Amagi a bit more. See
June Advanced CV
for calculator links.
For even more damage, adjust Unzen's torpedo reload time to be the same as the main fleet's reload time. Then she would both hit more and splash two bosses more.

This fleet won in 8:39 with mid cats and no submarines. If you don't have Bismarck Zwei. Lala is highly important as the replacement. Because BBs are unfavored against heavy bosses, you probably won't have enough DPS with SR or weaker UR BBs. So this is actually more like high end ships with mid end gear.

This fleet won in 5:35 with mid cats and no submarines. Bismarck Zwei pulls the bosses together, then Musashi and Soyuz can salvo in either order. We avoided giving Soyuz a highly-enhanced autoloader because that would make her iceberg barrage proc right after Bismarck fires, before the bosses have been pulled together.
We do not expect you to copy this. It has a low "success" rate, and multiple restarts may be needed to make it faster than
Advanced CV

. There's no black hole or vacuum in sight. Instead, the fleet relies on Royal Fortune to stack the bosses together. However, slowing one boss by 40% for 6s causes the other boss to overtake the slowed boss. Royal Fortune's slow needs to be combined with a freeze like Implacable's or Nakhimov's at the exact right time. Royal Fortune slows one boss, Implacable slows and then freezes when the two bosses are stacked together, and then Royal Fortune's slow wears off.

This strategy can fail in multiple ways. Even with frame-perfect timing, RNG can cause the bosses to not be stacked well enough for torpedos to splash them both. Or, the vanguard may ram the bosses and cause them to separate slightly. Furthermore, Royal Fortune does her slowing barrage a few more times before leaving the battle. If the barrage hits one boss and misses the other due to evasion, then the bosses will also separate.

Did you enjoy your vacation last month? The devs have the perfect welcoming back gift for you! This is the hardest month in Extreme Challenge, but there are some key pieces *cough* soyuz *cough* that can make it easy. We will cover strategies with and without Sovetsky Soyuz separately in each example fleet section.
Yukikaze's first ability is to block 100 hits every 20s. Similarly to
January's Katsuragi
, bring vanguard ships with high pellet count. The same list there works, except that shield-piercers like Z52 are not disadvantaged against Yukikaze.

The three lifebuoys each have 10k HP, 0 EVA, 0 LUCK, and 200 AA. They spawn in fixed positions and do not move. These coordinates mean that Bismarck Zwei's black hole cannot reach all lifebuoys, but Sovetsky Soyuz's iceberg barrage will target Yukikaze and splash all lifebuoys enough to kill them.

See the time graph below, which shows when BBs and CVs with 20s reload time land their attacks. You have a period of 1.8s between when the lifebuoys spawn and when they start healing Yukikaze. Due to carriers' airplane and payload travel time, it is infeasible to rely on them to wipe the lifebuoys.
This section is for manual only, and only months with a notable manual strategy may have a manual section.

If you have Soyuz, please just auto this. Otherwise, bring one or more carriers with good AoE damage like Tenrai's. At 9:42, 9:02, 8:22, and so on every 40s, dump your airstrikes to kill the lifebuoys. You will still need good anti-light damage to deal with Yukikaze even if she doesn't get healed.

Ships don't start reloading until 1.5s into the battle, which is still before the boss spawns. This delay means that a Sovetsky Soyuz with exactly 20s reload time will finish reloading 1.5s after the lifebuoys spawn. However, this is acceptable because Soyuz's barrage insta-kills the lifebuoys in the remaining 0.3s window before the lifebuoys start healing. Remember that Soyuz has a reload bonus when with at least one other battleship. We said exactly 20s, but 19.95s to 19.97s would be more ideal for safety from lag or poor RNG. You can even make Soyuz go as fast as 19.90s if you expect to win in under 5 minutes.
It is crucial for your other BBs to not interfere with Soyuz's reload. They must have
AFCT
HSFCR
and be at least as fast as 20s (preferably 18.9s to 19.6s), or they must be slower than Soyuz and also not take AFCT/HSFCR.

Yukikaze's movement cycle puts her in the middle before she summons the lifebuoys. However, after a few minutes, her movement cycle drifts far enough so that she will summon the lifebuoys before reaching the center. When Yukikaze does not return to the center in time, Soyuz's barrage will miss one or two lifebuoys because the barrage is aimed at Yukikaze. There is no way to sync Soyuz to both Yukikaze's movement and to the lifebuoy spawn times. Hence, you need to finish the battle quick enough or get lucky when Soyuz begins failing to insta-kill the lifebuoys.

This fleet won in 7:07 with mid cats, half tech, and no subs. Fu Shun was almost dead at 7 minutes. Consider using Tai Yuan, An Shan, or another good ship. Soyuz should end up at 199 or 200 RLD. In this example, level 125 + Love gives 166, the +3 gray autoloader gives 7, and tech gives 9. Then, 182 RLD plus 10% from Soyuz's skill ends at 200 RLD.
If you upgrade FdG to Bismarck Zwei or Vanguard, then they must use AFCT/HSFCR because they're faster than Soyuz.
Calculator link
Please read all of the
Soyuz BB

section first. The only differences are that Soyuz does not have a reload bonus with carriers and that carriers can not significantly interfere with Soyuz's reload, so it is even okay for them to be 20s and slightly faster or slightly slower than Soyuz. If you use Nakhimov, she will need to be around 20s to sync with Soyuz. Other carriers are more free in timing, but making them 20s too is still a good idea to take advantage of Soyuz's slow and small debuff. Soyuz should end up at 199 or 200 RLD.

In the first example, level 125 + Love gives 166, the +6 autoloader gives 26, and tech gives 8 for a total of 200. It was too hard to get the CVs down to 20s too, but we put Enterprise closely behind Fritz to cope on the 30% slow. This fleet won in 6:20 with mid cats, half tech with 27 CV RLD, and no subs.
Calculator link

This high-end fleet won in 4:22 with mid cats, half tech, and no subs. If unoathed, the tech and cats should give 55 CV RLD and 0 BB RLD. If you can't copy that, then calculate your own sync. Soyuz at 199 to 201 RLD (201 is acceptable because the fleet should win earlier), Nakhimov also around 20s to sync with Soyuz, and Fritz also around 20s to sync with Nakhimov. Also turn DD RLD tech to 8 or lower so that Fu Shun's SY-1A is slower than 20s, to avoid hitting Yukikaze's 1 dmg barrier.
Calculator link

This top-end fleet won in 3:25 with good cats, half tech, and no subs. We have a feeling that Helena did not scan much. If unoathed, the tech and cats should give 72 CV RLD and 0 BB RLD. The high RLD is needed to fit Skyraider to 20s. Chapayev makes her appearance for the first (and last for now) time in endgame content, since Yukikaze is the only difficult DD boss we have encountered.
Calculator link
Due to the 1.5s start-of-battle delay in reloading, battleships with 20s reload and without
AFCT
HSFCR

fire too late to land more than the first volley of the first battleship. Without Soyuz, an unreliable way is if your battleships reload faster than 20s, then it could work for a few minutes until they fire too long before the lifebuoys spawn. So it is better for non-Soyuz BB fleets to have one 20s BB with AFCT and two BBs that reload between 18.8s and 19.9s without AFCT. Blocking the faster BBs behind the slowest BB is also good for long sync.

You will still need some luck for the BBs to randomly splash all the lifebuoys. Sometimes, one may survive for a second, but you can outdamage its healing. Sometimes, you may get unlucky with a lifebuoy surviving for many seconds. At that moment, regret not having Soyuz.

This fleet won in 6:26 with good cats (Every and Drake), half tech with 12 BB RLD, and no subs. Unoathed Alsace with Mk 6 needs about 12 BB RLD to get to 20s reload. Obviously, if you have Bismarck Zwei, then use her. But because she will likely be the oldest UR who hasn't rerun by April 2025, we use Raffaello in the example. Despite Alsace usually doing more damage than Raffaello, we do not give Plymouth's flagship buff to Alsace, because much of Alsace's damage will be going into Yukikaze's 1 dmg barrier.

This is a straightforward but somewhat difficult DPS check. Takao's Steel Blade Stance (henceforth SBS) with 90% damage reduction lasts until you deal 20,000 damage to her. Effectively, this means if your fleet would have dealt 300,000 damage within 10s, then 200,000 of that damage becomes 20,000 and you are left with 120,000 damage dealt to Takao. Viewed from a different angle, if your fleet interrupts Takao 29 times over 10 minutes, then an effective 29 * 180,000 = 5,220,000 HP is added to Takao's base 5,230,000 HP.

You must have a well-synced main fleet that interrupts Takao's damage reduction and hits her within 10s, in every reload cycle. Also, your vanguard takes damage faster as the battle goes on, so if you need 9 or 10 minutes for your DPS level, then you will need a CB or Anchorage-level tank. And that's it, if your account is strong then you can brute force this month. If not, then there are some small optimizations to augment your DPS against SBS phases.

Takao's 90% damage reduction is coded as her taking -90% damage from each of FP-based, TRP-based, and AVI-based damage. This damage reduction does not affect damage-over-time effects like burn and flood. Effectively, burns and floods do 10x as much damage while Takao is in SBS.

Hypothetically, if you were to use TRP as your main source of damage for some reason, you might want to bring Noshiro Î¼ or Tanikaze/Matchless. They make the boss take +40% damage from TRP-based damage, and -90% + 40% = -50%. Going from 10% to 50% damage is a huge 5x increase in damage for the first 20,000 damage and a 1.4x increase for any extra damage after that. But nobody will use TRP as the main damage source. Fortunately, FP and AVI also have some ship skills that are additive with the -90%, albeit not as crazy as +40%.
Here is a list of recommended bonuses to consider against Takao:
Most
burns
last for 15s, so you may give Mk 7 to the second or third BB to fire, preferably not the first.
Most
armor breaks
give +8% to FP-based damage, effectively 1.8x damage to SBS. Guam and Ã„gir are natural candidates for BB fleets.
Scylla
gives +6% to AVI-based damage, effectively 1.6x damage to SBS. Make sure her torpedo reloads slightly faster than the CVs.
Floods
. There are not many ships who inflict flooding, and the good ships among them are even fewer.
This section is for manual only, and only months with a notable manual strategy may have a manual section.

Use carriers (with a freeze like Implacable or August of course) and wait for 40+ seconds until each carrier has two airstrikes ready. Dump them all at once. Repeat. This strategy effectively halves the number of -90% damage SBS you have to deal with, increasing your damage per minute.

This fleet won in 8:49 with mid cats, half tech, and no subs. Like CVs, BBs are quite bad without a slow or stop. But CVs have August von Parseval while BBs currently have no permanent option that's reliable. So we assume you have at least one of Bismarck Zwei, Eldridge Retrofit, or Sovetsky Soyuz.

In this example, Soyuz has the best gun damage and takes the UR SAP gun, making her the slowest of the BBs. This setup is quite convenient as we can give a single BB both SAP and AFCT to boost her damage, but don't try to force AFCT with SAP if it means using worse BBs. Vanguard must not be more than 1.2s faster than Soyuz. Giving her the Champagne gun is right around 1.2s, so it'll probably be fine, but using Soyuz gun if you have it is a safe play.

This fleet won in 5:35 with good cats (Every and Drake), half tech, and no subs. We tried to find a suitable timing for Kearsarge. Whether her burns and BB debuffs are worth this aux gimping is a valid question when Alsace also has a debuff and lesser burn. Since Soyuz is slowest but fires first due to AFCT, put her in the top position to activate Guam's armor break. The fleet would need about 9 BB/BBV RLD to maintain a 20s reload for Helena. If you have less, then remove Helena's SG Radar.
This fleet won in 9:29 with mid cats, half tech, and no subs.

If you use Scylla, make sure her torpedoes reload slightly faster or as fast as the fastest CV. In this example using 41 CV RLD after cats, Fritz is 20.96s, and Scylla with 13 CL RLD is 20.87s. Unfortunately, quad mag torpedoes would reload too fast even with 0 CL RLD and the Crossbow augment.

Franklin is a nice sidegrade to Enterprise and even has a flood. But in a 10 minute battle, she will burn herself for over 5000 HP, and Takao can also blind-fire Franklin if your whole main fleet is concealed. So don't use Franklin unless you also use Kearsarge.
This fleet won in 3:54 with the mid cats, half tech, and no subs. Maybe Helena scanned more than expected.

An example using 6 BB RLD and 48 CV RLD plus Bishamaru's staff skill. Higher reload would be better to allow for the main fleet to stay within Helena's scan for more strikes. The Soyuz Nakhimov Fritz main fleet is currently the best against most medium armor bosses, and Takao is no exception. The more La-9's the better, but try to find a tight enough sync for how long you expect the battle to take.

Every 27s, Chelae the claw attempts to grab your vanguard. If it is successful and survives for 9s, Spee heals for 5% max HP. There are two ways to avoid Spee's healing.
There is a 1.2s delay between the claw's aim and the claw's grab. Using a fast vanguard greatly increases the chance of the claw missing.

Use BBs' secondary guns to kill the claw within 9s. This is quite difficult and inconsistent even with 3 BBs. For example, the vanguard and claw could be too far down or right for the top BB to hit it. You will also need high vanguard DPS to help.

The claw, being a real enemy, increases your CV detection gauge when it is to the left of the blue detection line (please turn on the "Display CV Detection Line" setting if you haven't already). If you use one or more CVs, it is highly important to use a fast vanguard or manual.
Warning: Spee does a lot of damage to both vanguard and main fleet.

Spee regularly attacks a revealed ship in the main fleet. Your flagship is most likely to be the target if she is revealed. She can die in 4 to 6 minutes without survival gear. If you don't have a strong fleet to win fast, then give your BB a
washing machine
if the other 2 are concealed carriers, or give the same to your flagship if you use multiple BBs.

Using 3 carriers is not safe from the above attack due to carriers' naturally increasing detection from airstrikes or barrages. Furthermore, Spee regularly fires a burning barrage like many other CM bosses if the whole main fleet is concealed. Scepter is a must, and a washing machine on the carrier who is most likely to be revealed may be advisable.
For the vanguard, bring a real main tank while keeping speed high with
Beaver Badge
, Boilers,
based Boiler
Cosmic Kicks
, and/or
better Cosmic Kicks
This section is for manual only, and only months with a notable manual strategy may have a manual section.
Move your vanguard in a straight line in any direction to avoid the claw.
This fleet won in 6:23 with oaths, 20% tech, mid cats, and no submarines. The whole vanguard and Shinano had less than 15% HP remaining.
Shinano Amagi Implacable for the "poor" players. This exact gear works up to a maximum of 60 CV RLD. But if you have La-9(s), you really should calculate a sync for them for much more damage.
Calculator link
This fleet won in 3:47 with oaths, half tech, mid cats, and no submarines.

Standard Soyuz-Nakhimov sync. This example used 37 CV RLD and 9 BB RLD. You can try to add more La-9. This is expected to win in less than 5 minutes, so survivability is not a big focus of the example gear.
Calculator link
This fleet won in 4:25 with 20% tech, mid cats, and no submarines. Lion had low HP.
Note: Any resemblance to a faction fleet is purely coincidental, and we vehemently deny forcing Neptune and Warspite in.

Seriously, use a better tank than Neptune. And Warspite is a real UR BB now with her unique augment, but she's still a bottom tier UR BB. Lion (and Alsace) can store salvos, so she should be the blocker with AFCT/HSFCR for a long-lasting sync. The other two BBs should be faster by 0.1s to 1.1s and not use AFCT or HSFCR.
Calculator link
This fleet won in 3:18 with half tech, mid cats, and no submarines.

Same theory as above (and every other BB fleet in CM) - use Lion to block the other BBs. Eldridge for slow and survivability. Slowing the boss is useful even with Bismarck Zwei, because her black hole only lasts for 3s while a triple BB fleet's salvo lasts for 6+ seconds.
Calculator link
This fleet won in 3:20 with half tech, mid cats, and no submarines.

Four-salvo hybrid fleets are all the rage in META Showdown these days. The carriers use faster planes with less damage in order to sync with BBs and fit four strikes in 80s. Will the same be worth it in CM over slapping 4 La-9's? Find out in our next episo....

This is a CM that can be very annoying due to various sources of lag and RNG. However, do not be scared by the double Hard
. If you time Unicorn precisely, then the Tank check is naturally solved. Or if you bring tanks and Perseus, then Perseus trivializes the timing precision.

You must either bring a vanguard heal that activates every 20s, or have carriers that reload slightly faster than 20s for a screen clear. Toolkits alone will not do the job. The best ways to get the heal are
Primary Healers (Recommended)

Unicorn, who has the benefit of doing more damage and healing than Perseus. Must be timed properly, 19.92s-19.93s probably works for 5-7 minutes, and 19.94s-19.96s probably works for 10 minutes. For a level 125 Unicorn in love,
BF-109G
and
Ryuusei
is 19.95s in-game with 2 RLD tech (also try 3 RLD if 2 doesn't work), or use
HVARcat
and
Ju-87d
with 0 RLD tech.
Do not bring cats with CVL RLD.
Passing the first few stings relies on RNG, because if your vanguard is too close to the boss then they'll get hit before Unicorn heals.

Perseus, who suffers from low damage and lower healing. She struggles to keep a sandwiched Aurora alive, so Eldridge is needed. A Plymouth-Aurora-Eldridge vanguard can survive for 7 minutes, which may not be enough time if your main fleet is weak. Furthermore, if her heal lags less than Elbing's sting, then Perseus can cleanse your vanguard of venom right before Scorpion's Mist (which lasts for 2s) expires. If your ships are moving, they regain the venom by touching Scorpion's Mist.
Minor Healers (not recommended due to how much damage the boss does)
Little Formidable requires >90% HP, so to avoid her being burnt, bring at least one non-concealed main fleet ship, or pray with a full carrier fleet.
Marseillaise for a full-French vanguard.
Boise Î¼ with a level 8 healing skill.
Ognevoy has a 10s heal, but she desyncs after like 5 minutes due to activating 4x as much as Elbing's skill.

Due to a possible bug, most vanguard ships get the +60% damage buff permanently, even if they get healed. Ships who gain, lose, or refresh another source of damageRatioBullet, like Bayard or Bremerton, lose the free +60% damage until the next venom mist. Also, damage may be tight so GLHF if you don't have Aurora.
This section is for manual only, and only months with a notable manual strategy may have a manual section.

If you have fast reflexes, you can use a carrier's airstrike to clear the Fatal Sting barrage before it hits your vanguard. Keep to the left edge of the screen so that you have more time to use the airstrike. Manual should allow you to forgo a healer for more damage.
This fleet and gear won in 7:25 using half tech, a random gold/purple submarine fleet with random torps and no synergy, and the free cats level 30 Drake and level 25 Every.
Any oaths or tech, just keep the faster black-white shell BB blocked behind the slower BB who is using
AFCT
HSFCR
Same explanation as
High-End BB 1
. But with Ognevoy instead of Unicorn, the fleet has to win faster due to Ognevoy's sync drift and the lack of healing.

Again, any oaths or tech, just keep the faster black-white shell BBs blocked behind the slower BB with AFCT/HSFCR. Removing Aurora and Plymouth is a big loss in DPS, but the extra BB may recover some of it. Marseillaise is required because she heals French ships every 20s. Elbing does a lot of damage, so Brest is required if your battle will go longer than 5 minutes. The third ship can be Le Mars for fleet buff, Mogador for damage, or L'Audacieux for worse Mogador.

For the super lazy people who don't want to time Unicorn, you can use Unicorn and Perseus together. This fleet won in 9:49 with no subs, half tech, a single cat without flame, and no HVARcat or Skyraider.

Forgo healing and use CV screenclear to wipe the sting barrage. This requires carriers to be slightly faster than 20s, which is a high bar for CVs but not CVLs like Unicorn. Due to the 1.5s start of battle delay, if your faster CV has exactly 20.0s reload, the screen clear will happen 0.5s after the boss fires the true damage barrage. If your vanguard is too close to the boss due to RNG, then they'll die in that 0.5s. So you want CVs to reload slightly faster than 20s but not so fast that the CVs strike before the barrage appears.
Or just be a normal person and use the other fleets.

First, read the boss skills if you haven't. You must consistently interrupt Warspite every 20s, and not mentioned is that her charge attack has 30k HP and finishes in 5s. Let "success" denote your fleet successfully interrupting Warspite by dealing enough damage. Let "failure" denote the opposite. Generally, a success causes your main fleet to lose a little HP, and a failure causes it to lose a LOT of HP. Do not expect to tank two or more failures.

On average, the charge attack happens every ~20.05s, and Warspite stops for ~8.2s (shown in the chart below) every ~20.45s. Strategies that attempt to take advantage of her stop should consider that timing attacks to her charge attack will become desynced with her stop later in the battle.

One recurring strategy you will find in the following fleets is a BB (excluding Alsace) or Unzen with 20s reload time. After one failure, Warspite will blind your fleet, preventing torpedos, airstrikes, and main fleet salvos from launching. The blindness ends around the same time Warspite begins the next charge. Since BBs and Unzen cannot begin reloading the next attack while holding one, they will become synced with Warspite's charging for the rest of the battle.
Unfortunately, this CM is hard. Try your best to copy one of the High-End fleets with Helena, and manual for clearing barrages or hitting stop times if you need to.

The least-effort strategy that may randomly lose even when geared well. The BBs have no sync whatsoever, so they fire at arbitrary times, with UvH offering frequent salvos. Every 20s, pray that at least one BB's salvo partially falls within the 5s charge attack window, and some high-DPS vanguard ships can also help reach the 30k threshold. The fleet is expected to get a few interrupt failures, so you should also pray that your BBs evade enough shells.

In fleets with non-concealed ship(s), Warspite will fire additional AP barrages at your main fleet ships, especially Musashi or the flagship. These barrages chip away your BBs' HP, so it is a DPS race. If you don't have three good vanguard ships like Eldridge, Aegir, Plymouth, Unzen, Hindenburg, Guam, or Helena, then you could try putting a ship with Flank Defense or Flagship Cover.
If you put in more effort, you can try to get Unzen's torpedos or one of the BBs to have around 20s reload time. Then, the fleet will win more consistently.

Because carriers (except Impero) can store airstrikes, being blinded once by Warspite will not sync the 20s carriers to the charge attack. Therefore, these fleets must rely on the vanguard to deal 30k damage in 5s. If you can get the vanguard damage to work, then ~20s CVs with Helena should produce the fastest possible clear times.
Warning: Unzen's 20.0s to 20.1s (improved) quad mag torpedos are basically required.

Shown here is an unoathed Unzen with 10 CA RLD tech and a +4 Autoloader yielding a faster reload than 20.0s, but Unzen can be lagged or blocked so 19.98s is suitable. Ideally you should find a sync with one or two oxytorps instead of autoloader. The example could have put two oxytorps, but the autoloader+toolkit was chosen for people who win slower. Shinano, being the slowest of the three carriers, takes defensive auxes to survive for over 5 minutes.
This is a 2023 video using Hakuryuu instead of Amagi(CV), but the idea is identical.

An alternate version with Admiral Nakhimov but requries very high CV RLD and damage. Since there is no other Northern Parliament slow, we need Royal Fortune to provide slow as well. Because of the high CV reload tech, after Royal Fortune leaves, the CVs have caught up to Warspite's stop times.
Chapter 15 enemy smokescreens.
Every 30s, two Mass-Produced Kagerou Class spawn off screen. The first spawn is at 2:42 for (all? I didnt check) chapter 15 battles.

These Mass-Produced Kagerou Class slowly move left to eventually crash into your main fleet. They do not have to be killed for the battle to end. They have 40 SPD with a 0.4 multiplier for 16 effective SPD.
After spawning, each Mass-Produced Kagerou Class spawns a tiny smokescreen on itself, every 0.8s, for 6 times.

After each smokescreen spawns, it expands over 3s, with a quadratic rate of expanstion, to around 21x56 size (can be smaller if your potato device skips calculation frames). Then it disappears after 12s more, for a total duration of 15s.
Enemies who touched the smokescreen get aim bias, not an EVA rate buff.

Enemies in smoke, enemies in night weather, and allied vanguard/subs in night weather have an aim bias represented by a bar above the unit. Aim bias causes the opposing side's attacks to be aimed randomly within a square centered on the unit, and the square's size depends on the fullness of the bar and other factors. On this page, "concealment" refers to aim bias of vanguard ships, submarines, and enemy ships, not to main fleet concealment.

Enemies that leave the smokescreen are Exposed, removing aim bias and pausing the decay. Re-entering the smokescreen within 3 seconds resumes aim bias but does not reset it to max. If the enemy does not re-enter a smokescreen within 3 seconds of being Exposed, the aim bias will start at max when the enemy enters a smokescreen.
The aim bias bar decays with a speed based on complex formulas. Aim bias is measured in "units" and decay speeds are in units per second.

content.snippet: combinedSpeed = decaySpeedRatio * maxAimBias + decaySpeedFog + decaySpeedHit + decaySpeedRadar

content.text: In Chapter 14, when you wipe an enemy wave, there are no enemies on screen.
But this is 0 at the beginning of the battle even though enemies haven't spawned yet.

While battling enemy fleets that are located inside the foggy weather on a Chapter 14 sortie map, all allied and enemy ships get aim bias decay speed -0.15, meaning that all ships stay concealed for longer.

Applies in both Chapters 14 and 15. The HIT stat of the ship with the highest HIT stat on either side (friend or foe, excluding support carriers) will affect the rate of decay of the opposing side's aim bias. Submarines are only affected by the highest HIT stat among the opposing side's DD, CL, and DDG(V). This effect is capped to 300 HIT on the highest-HIT ship.
Each ship equipped with a radar-like gear (excluding support carriers) makes the enemy aim bias decay
very slightly
quicker. Applies in both Chapters 14 and 15. Two radar-like gear on one ship only counts as one.
This is the list of "radar-like" gear as of May 2025, and they all add a constant 0.1 to the decay speed:

content.text: Most fighters and a few other airplanes have passive interception, henceforth referred to as "interception." Look at the fire rate (FR) of an airplane in your depot or on your ship. If it has a drop-down that says "Intercept RoF," then that airplane can intercept.

As with other weapons, carriers' RLD stat affects Intercept RoF. In flight, the anti-air effectiveness of the intercepting aircraft depends on the mother carrier's level, current stats (AVI and RLD), and current airplane slot efficiency. Technically, HIT and LUCK matter too, but because enemy airplanes have only 1 EVA, differences in HIT and LUCK make less than a 1% difference through crit rate.
Note: Interception works entirely independently of carriers' main airstrikes and skill (barrage) airstrikes.

When an enemy airplane is doing a strafing run (in PvE, it's going from right to left) and your interceptor is off cooldown, the carrier launches the interceptor. When one plane is launched, it puts the carrier's interception queue in cooldown for 0.5s, preventing all other intercepting planes from launching during this time. In effect, this means that each plane launches 0.6s after the previous if it is ready. For example, an Illustrious with Flapjack, Focke-Wulf 190 A-5, and Wyvern will launch 8 planes (3 Flapjacks, 3 fw190a5, and 2 Wyverns) with 0.6s between each, taking 4.2s to finish. After around 3s more, the first Flapjack to launch will finish its ~7s cooldown. Each airplane has its own cooldown, and each carrier has her own interception queue cooldown.
Then, the airplanes use their guns to shoot enemy airplanes.
In Chapter 15, support carriers use their levels, stats (AVI and RLD), and fighter efficiencies. Skills, cats, and crossfleet buffs do NOT take effect.

The support carriers are spawned at the flagship's normal position (if you put Odin as flagship, you might see airplanes appearing from thin air/water), but they cannot be seen, interacted with, or killed. They launch intercepting fighters and only intercepting fighters.
Warning: Wyvern, Breguet, and all other DB/TBs do NOT intercept when equipped on a support carrier. They only act as AVI statsticks.

Unlike normal carriers which check for enemy planes, support carriers launch their intercepting fighters as soon as they're off cooldown. For example, around 8s after the start of battle, an Illustrious with Flapjack, Focke-Wulf 190 A-5, and Wyvern will launch 3 flapjacks with 0.6s between each, wait around 1s more, then launch 3 fw190a5 with 0.6s between each.
Note: The coordinate system is 3D. X is horizontal left to right, Z is vertical bottom to top of your screen, and Y is mostly unimportant.
when the airplane is first launched, it is unable to attack for 1.5s. It chooses targetZ as a random Z coordinate in the middle three fifths of the vanguard movement field.
while the airplane is alive,
X-speed is constant and depends on the Plane Speed advertised on the equipment.
Z-speed is equal to 0.5 in the direction from the airplane's Z coordinate to its targetZ.
If the targetZ has been reached, then roll another random targetZ.
Thus, airplanes zigzag vertically while flying horizontally across the screen.

Gold Single 113mm vs Blue Single 76mm, which is better? The answer isn't immediately obvious because the Blue Single 76mm reloads faster, and the whole point of using one of these two guns is to shoot more.
Image
Base Reload
Range
Cost
"Free"
FP
Damage
Armor Mod
Shell Range
Conclusion first in case you don't want to read.
First, make sure the ship actually wants one of these guns.

As of May 2025, the most relevant of these ships are Trafalgar, Z52, and Kazagumo. Other somewhat notable examples include Shimakaze, Nana, Kawakaze, Z47, and Scylla (the last of whom can also use Twin 100mm Kai).
New player or haven't finished the priority gear lab crafts? Blue 76.
Don't care about minmaxing? Either gun.
RLD thresholds.
Goldburn
is always a safe choice for increasing RLD. Autoloader or Oxytorp depends on your ship's survival.
290 <= RLD or preferably 291 <= RLD? Gold 113.
270 <= RLD <= 289? Either gun.
RLD <= 253? Gold 113.
270 RLD is an untested spot. The threshold may be slightly higher or lower, but it doesn't matter much.
Bonus: You want to pay 120 gold plates for a 2% damage bonus to a single vanguard ship? +13 Gold 113.

Note: RLD stat is calculated as the white plus green plus yellow number on the ship screen. Skill percentage multipliers are applied after, but very few ships have that. The RLD is 310 in the following example.

Vanguard guns operate at a frequency of 10 Hertz. That is, they attempt to fire 10 times per second. A gun that reloads in 0.45s and the same gun that reloads in 0.47s are identical in reality because they are both rounded up to 0.50s. Meanwhile, a gun that reloads in 0.50s is unpredictable, because it can go at 0.50s or 0.60s randomly depending on device lag. Other factors that affect vanguard firing rate, such as animation trigger time, are outside the scope of this article.

From a pure minmaxing perspective, the only advantage of the Blue 76 over Gold 113 is its reload time. Everything else is worse. Hence, Blue 76 only has a chance to beat Gold 113 if it crosses a 10 Hertz threshold. In most maxed out destroyers' cases, that threshold is 0.50s. In the following tests, we explored different reload values on the ship to see whether Blue 76 can beat Gold 113 at certain reload values.

We tested the two guns using these setups on an oathed Z52. The torpedo was unequipped to reduce variance because her torpedo salvos are irrelevant to the test between the guns and barrages. An oathed Z52 with 200 affinity has 245 base RLD, and +10 Autoloader takes it to 280. For DD RLD tech values ranging from 0 to 27, our Z52 had 280 to 307 RLD. Because Blue 76 reloads faster, another option dropping the Autoloader for the All Work, All Play Robot was tested.

We battled Scharnhorst META showdown using this Z52 with various settings of DD RLD tech and both guns. Each gun and reload was tested several times, with the central Gold 113 threshold of 290 and 291 RLD being tested 10 times each to get a more confident average.

The main fleet consisted of Vestal and Zuihou for healing without adding damage bias, plus Chaser with double ASW planes. The other vanguard ships were Jeanne and Eldridge, both equipped with anti-submarine weapons to reduce variance on Z52's ASW damage. Also note that Scharnhorst META is medium armor, and Blue 76 is slightly favored against medium.
Note: The gold and light blue line (non-WorkPlay) lose 7 FP from Autoloader for the data points below 279 RLD.
Note: Results may vary slightly depending on device lag.

Gold 113, represented by the gold line, has a large jump between 290 and 291 RLD. At 291 and above, it is clearly superior to Blue 76. Below that, it is similar to Blue 76 for any RLD stat and any auxiliary gear.

Why such a large jump between 290 and 291 RLD? Although the game shows 0.50s for both due to rounding, that's where Gold 113 goes from 0.5000816527s to 0.4994417526s reload time. What a coincidence!! It's also not completely flat on either side due to the randomness in device lag. So 292 is better than 291, and 289 is worse than 290 RLD. Similarly, for Blue 76, there is a large difference between 253 and 254 RLD. But what happened to Gold 113 between 265 and 272 RLD? There's no reload time breakpoint there. We currently don't have any ideas to explain it.

Final note: Compared to a torpedo boat like Shimakaze, Z52 certainly does have a stronger main gun slot that can benefit from Gold 113's damage. Against light, medium, and heavy bosses respectively, Z52 with +10 Gold 113 has her main gun accounting for 10%, 5%, and 2% of her total damage respectively. We did not calculate Shimakaze, but her anti-heavy damage is probably less than 1% main gun. For torpedo ships, the Gold 113's damage advantage is suppressed, leaving nearly only the range and reload difference. So there is a possibility that Blue 76 is better for them at more RLD values.
